text: The <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunit of NF-kappa B regulates I kappa B by two distinct mechanisms .

Transcription factor NF-kappa B ( <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is generally localized to the cytoplasm by its inhibitor I kappa B . Overproduced I kappa B , free from NF-kappa B , is rapidly degraded .

Overexpression of <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> increases endogenous I kappa B protein in both carcinoma and lymphoid cells by two mechanisms : protein stabilization and increased transcription of I kappa B mRNA .
In contrast , <extra_id_0> p65 delta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a naturally occurring splice variant , fails to markedly augment I kappa B protein levels .

Both overexpressed <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and coexpressed <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are cytoplasmic , whereas <extra_id_0> p65 delta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is partly nuclear , indicating that the I kappa B induced by <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can maintain NF-kappa B in the cytoplasm .

Thus , <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and I kappa B are linked in an autoregulatory loop , ensuring that NF-kappa B is held in the cytoplasm until cells are specifically induced to translocate it to the nucleus .
